questions.question: Segment reporting is required for:

options.B: Public companies whose securities are traded on public markets
options.D: Companies with more than $100 million in revenue

questions.explanation: ASC 280 requires segment reporting for public entities whose debt or equity securities are traded in public markets or that are in the process of issuing such securities.
questions.tip: Segment reporting: required for public companies.

questions.question: Under the management approach, operating segments are identified based on:

options.B: Geographic regions
options.C: How management organizes the entity for making operating decisions and assessing performance

questions.explanation: The management approach identifies segments based on how the chief operating decision maker (CODM) organizes the entity internally for decision-making and performance evaluation.
questions.tip: Management approach: segments match internal reporting.

questions.question: An operating segment must have all of the following characteristics EXCEPT:

options.A: Engages in business activities that may generate revenues and incur expenses
options.B: Operating results are regularly reviewed by the CODM

questions.explanation: Operating segments must: engage in revenue/expense activities, have results reviewed by CODM, and have discrete financial information. There's no specific revenue threshold for being an operating segment.
questions.tip: No minimum revenue to BE an operating segment.

questions.question: An operating segment is separately reportable if it meets any of the following thresholds:

options.B: 10% of revenue, assets, or absolute value of profit/loss

questions.explanation: An operating segment is reportable if its revenue, assets, or the absolute value of its profit/loss is 10% or more of the combined totals of all operating segments.
questions.tip: 10% test: revenue, assets, or profit/loss (absolute value).

questions.question: The 75% test requires that reportable segments must represent at least 75% of:

options.B: Total combined operating segment revenue

questions.explanation: The 75% test requires that reportable segments must include enough segments so that their external revenues equal at least 75% of consolidated external revenues.
questions.tip: 75% test = enough segments to cover 75% of external revenue.

questions.question: Required disclosures for reportable segments include:

options.B: Factors used to identify segments, products/services, and specified financial information

questions.explanation: Segment disclosures include: how segments are determined, products/services, segment profit/loss, segment assets, and reconciliations to consolidated amounts.
questions.tip: Segment disclosures: identification + financials + reconciliation.

questions.question: Enterprise-wide geographic disclosures require reporting:

options.B: Revenues from external customers and long-lived assets by country if material

questions.explanation: Geographic disclosures require revenues from external customers and long-lived assets attributed to the domestic country and foreign countries (separately if material).
questions.tip: Geographic: revenue and long-lived assets by country.

questions.question: Disclosure about major customers is required when:

options.A: Any customer represents more than 5% of revenue
options.B: Any single customer represents 10% or more of total revenue
options.C: The company has fewer than 10 customers

questions.explanation: If revenues from a single external customer are 10% or more of total enterprise revenue, the entity must disclose that fact, the amount from each such customer, and the segment(s) reporting those revenues.
questions.tip: Major customer disclosure: ≥10% of total revenue.

questions.question: Total revenue of all operating segments is $50 million. Which segment is reportable under the revenue test?

options.B: Segment B with $5 million revenue

questions.explanation: 10% threshold = $50 million × 10% = $5 million. Only Segment B meets this threshold exactly.
questions.tip: Segment revenue ≥ 10% of combined = reportable.

questions.question: The chief operating decision maker (CODM) is:

options.B: A function, not necessarily a single individual, that allocates resources and assesses performance

questions.explanation: The CODM is a function, which may be the CEO, a group of executives, or the board. The function allocates resources to and assesses performance of operating segments.
questions.tip: CODM = function (may be individual or group).

questions.question: Under U.S. GAAP, interim periods are viewed as:

options.B: Integral parts of the annual period
options.C: Either discrete or integral, depending on the company

questions.explanation: U.S. GAAP views interim periods as integral parts of the annual period. This affects how certain items (like taxes and bonuses) are allocated across quarters.
questions.tip: GAAP: interim = integral part of annual.

questions.question: Revenue recognition principles for interim periods are:

options.B: The same as annual periods

questions.explanation: Revenue recognition principles are the same for interim and annual periods. Revenue is recognized when performance obligations are satisfied, regardless of the reporting period.
questions.tip: Interim revenue = same rules as annual.

questions.question: Interim income tax expense is typically computed using:

options.B: The estimated annual effective tax rate applied to year-to-date income

questions.explanation: Interim tax expense is calculated by applying the estimated annual effective tax rate to year-to-date ordinary income, then determining the current period's portion.
questions.tip: Interim tax: estimated annual effective rate × YTD income.

questions.question: Q1 pre-tax income is $100,000; Q2 is $150,000. Estimated annual effective tax rate is 30%. What is Q2 income tax expense?
questions.tip: Q2 tax = (YTD income × rate) - Q1 tax expense.

questions.question: When inventory market value declines below cost in an interim period but is expected to recover by year-end:

options.A: The loss must be recognized immediately
options.B: The loss may be deferred if recovery is expected
options.D: The loss is split over remaining quarters

questions.explanation: If inventory market decline is expected to be temporary and recover by year-end, the loss may be deferred. However, if not expected to recover, it must be recognized immediately.
questions.tip: Interim inventory loss: defer if recovery expected by year-end.

questions.question: If a temporary LIFO liquidation occurs in an interim period but is expected to be replaced by year-end:

options.B: Charge cost of sales at expected replacement cost
options.C: Use FIFO for that quarter only

questions.explanation: For temporary LIFO liquidations expected to be replaced, cost of sales is charged at expected replacement cost (not the old LIFO cost). This prevents temporary earnings distortion.
questions.tip: Temporary LIFO liquidation: use replacement cost in interim.

questions.question: Costs that benefit more than one interim period should be:

options.A: Expensed entirely in the first quarter
options.B: Allocated among periods benefited on a reasonable basis

questions.explanation: Costs benefiting multiple interim periods (like annual insurance) should be allocated on a systematic and rational basis to the periods that benefit.
questions.tip: Multi-period costs: allocate to periods benefited.

questions.question: For highly seasonal businesses, annual costs should be:

options.B: Expensed as incurred, even if creating interim losses
options.D: Recognized in the fourth quarter only

questions.explanation: Costs are generally expensed as incurred. For seasonal businesses, this may result in losses in off-season quarters. Arbitrary allocation is not permitted.
questions.tip: Seasonal business: expense as incurred, may have interim losses.

questions.question: Material unusual or infrequent items in interim periods should be:

options.B: Recognized in the interim period in which they occur

questions.explanation: Unusual or infrequent items are recognized in the interim period when they occur, not spread over multiple periods or deferred.
questions.tip: Unusual items: recognize in period incurred.

questions.question: An accounting change made in an interim period is applied:

options.B: Retrospectively as if made at the beginning of the fiscal year
options.D: Prospectively from the quarter of change

questions.explanation: Accounting changes in interim periods are applied retrospectively, including restatement of previously reported interim periods of that fiscal year, as if the change was made at year's beginning.
questions.tip: Interim accounting change: retroactive to beginning of fiscal year.

questions.question: Minimum interim disclosures include:

options.B: Sales/revenues, seasonal aspects, unusual items, contingencies, and changes in accounting

questions.explanation: Minimum interim disclosures include: sales, seasonal revenue variations, unusual items, contingency changes, accounting changes, segment information, and other material items.
questions.tip: Interim disclosures: key items, not full annual detail.

questions.question: Two or more operating segments may be aggregated if they have similar:

options.B: Economic characteristics and similar products, production, customers, distribution, and regulatory environment

questions.explanation: Aggregation is permitted if segments have similar economic characteristics and are similar in all of: nature of products/services, production processes, customer types, distribution methods, and regulatory environment.
questions.tip: Aggregation: similar economics + 5 qualitative factors.

questions.question: Segment disclosures must include reconciliations between:

options.B: Total segment amounts and consolidated financial statement amounts

questions.explanation: Reconciliations are required between total segment revenues, profit/loss, assets, and other significant items to the corresponding consolidated amounts.
questions.tip: Reconcile: segment totals to consolidated totals.

questions.question: When year-end adjustments significantly affect Q4 results:

options.A: They should be allocated to all quarters
options.B: The nature and amount must be disclosed in Q4 or annual report
options.C: They should be deferred to the next year

questions.explanation: Material year-end adjustments affecting Q4 must be disclosed, including their nature and amount, to avoid misleading quarterly comparisons.
questions.tip: Material Q4 adjustments require disclosure.

questions.question: ASC 280 suggests that the number of reportable segments:

options.B: Should generally not exceed 10

questions.explanation: While there's no strict maximum, ASC 280 notes that if the number of reportable segments exceeds 10, the entity should consider whether a practical limit has been reached.
questions.tip: Practical limit: ~10 reportable segments.
